bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Wade H. Frost, [February 1922]

div1.p: Carter writes that he would be glad to give lectures on malaria and yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Wade H. Frost, [February 1922]
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
, D. C.
Surgeon W. H. Frost,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Professor of Epidemiology,
School of Hygiene & Public Health,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Doctor Frost:
div1.p:
I will be glad to give the three lectures--2 on malaria and one
on yellow fever--for which you ask.

One hour will be as long as I would care to talk. If you think
it advisable, however, I could take the 1 1/2 hours interval--allow-
ing one hour for the lecture and the half hour thereafter for ques-
tions from the class. This was the habit at the Laboratory lectures
here. This just as you judge best for the class.

I expect to have to go to South Carolina about March 1st.--not
certain of it--and I judge that the dates that would suit me best
would be: Malaria--Tuesday, March 7th.: Thursday, March 9th. and
Yellow Fever --Tuesday, March 14th. I would prefer the morning
hours for the two Tuesdays, but this is really a matter of small
importance and if the afternoon suits other arrangements better, it
makes no difference to me: Nor indeed does the day, as long as I
allow time--up to March 6th.--for my possible trip to S. C.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
